title: National Theatre severs Shell partnership declaring action needed to avoid 'environmental collapse'
text:
The National Theatre (NT) has severed its partnership with Shell in response to climate concerns just days after the Royal Shakespeare Company (RSC) split with BP.

Their affiliation will end in just eight months, with the cultural institution declaring that emergency action is needed to solve ecological issues and avoid "catastrophic environmental collapse".

It says the theatre impacts the environment because it uses raw materials and energy to make temporary sets, and requires people to "travel to a particular location at a particular time" to watch performances.

In a statement, the NT said: "Shell have been valued and long-standing supporters of the National Theatre, most recently as corporate members - this membership will come to an end in June 2020."

The announcement comes just three days after the RSC ended its relationship with multinational BP following high-profile opposition to fossil fuel sponsorship.

Acclaimed actor Sir Mark Rylance, an RSC associate of 30 years, quit in June in protest over oil industry ties.

Last week school students threatened to boycott the company if it did not cut ties with BP, sending it a letter describing the partnership as "sickening".

The NT has said the theatre will now examine the way it operates and make alterations to be more environmentally friendly.
